sentence: Chicago, IL - June 22, 2015 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog.
Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets.

Stocks recently featured in the blog include the United Technologies Corp. ( UTX ), Procter & Gamble Company ( PG ), Coty Inc. ( COTY ), General Electric Company ( GE ) and Cisco Systems Inc. ( CSCO ).
Today, Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.
Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free .

Here are highlights from Friday's Analyst Blog:

The Dow enjoyed another week of gains, suffering its only reverse on Monday.
A setback in bailout talks between Greece and its creditors over the weekend continued to negatively impact benchmarks on Monday.
The blue-chip index gained on Tuesday as investors brushed off concerns about Greek debt crisis and focused on the outcome of the Fed meeting.
Stocks ended Wednesday's choppy trading session slightly higher after Fed officials said the economy is ready for a rate hike this year.
The blue-chip index gained 1% on Thursday after the Federal Reserve hinted that it will move slowly on raising interest rates.
The Dow has gained 1.2% during the first four trading days.
A setback in bailout talks between Greece and its creditors over the weekend continued to negatively impact benchmarks on Monday.
The European Commission warned that talks failed due to "significant gap between the plans of the Greek authorities and the joint requirements of the commission, European Central Bank and the IMF."
The Dow declined 0.6%.
Greece's creditors were in talks to extend Greece's bailout program until the end of Mar 2016 in return for pension cuts and tax hikes to be implemented by Athens.
However, Greek Prime Minister Alexi Tsipras refused to implement pension reforms and tax increases to achieve budget surpluses as demanded by Greece's lenders.
Meanwhile, manufacturing activity worsened slightly for New York manufacturers and decline in U.S. industrial production in May added to the bearish sentiment.
Industrial production fell 0.2% in May after decreasing 0.5% in April.
Additionally, the Empire State Manufacturing Survey Index came in at a negative 1.98 in June.
The Dow gained 0.6% on Tuesday as investors brushed off concerns about the Greek debt crisis, which weighed heavily on markets in the previous two trading days.
Instead, they remained focused on the outcome of Fed's two-day policy meeting that concludes on Wednesday.
Investors are looking for clues on when the Fed officials will start raising rates.
Meanwhile, news on mergers and acquisitions also offset worries over Greece's financial crisis.
Additionally, a rise in building permits boosted investor sentiment.
Building permits increased at a rate of 11.8% in May to 1,275,000 from April's revised figure of 1,140,000.
The annual pace of permits for new construction hit the fastest pace since Aug 2007.
Stocks ended Wednesday's choppy trading session slightly higher after Fed officials said the economy is ready for a rate hike this year.
An overwhelming majority of Federal Reserve officials believe that the improving U.S. economy is strong enough to withstand one or two rate hikes this year.
The central bank wants to see continued improvement in the labor market and inflation rate moving closer to its target rate of 2% before hiking rates.
Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen said that "some progress" has been made on these two criteria but "room for further improvement remains."
The Fed Chair noted that the economy has "expanded moderately".
Meanwhile, Yellen emphasized that the timing of a rate hike isn't important; instead the focus should be on the pace and trajectory of rate hikes.
The blue-chip index gained 0.2%.
The Dow gained 1% on Thursday after the Federal Reserve hinted that it will move slowly on raising interest rates.
Meanwhile, CPI gained 0.4% in May, the biggest gain since Feb 2013.
Additionally, jobless claims in mid-June declined to a near-15-year low, boosting investor sentiment.
Unemployment benefits dropped last week to a near-15-year bottom.
Initial claims declined 12,000 for the week ending June 13 to 267,000, lower than the consensus estimate of 276,500.
Moreover, the 4-week moving average also decreased 2,000 from previous week's level to 276,750.

United Technologies Corp. ( UTX ) recently revised its guidance for 2015 as it completed the review for exploring strategic alternatives for its helicopter business - Sikorsky Aircraft Corp. Gregory Hayes, the President and Chief Executive Officer of the company, debriefed investors through a press release that Sikorsky will be likely spun off or sold in the near future.
European companies seeking to enter the U.S. helicopter manufacturing market could be potential candidates for the Sikorsky bid.
Others are also exploring options for the buyout if the business is put up for sale.
United Technologies currently expects earnings to be in the range of $6.35 to $6.55 per share on revenues of $58 billion to $59 billion, excluding contributions from Sikorsky.
Organic growth is expected to be 3%-5% and cash flow from operations less capital expenditures in the range of 90% to 100% of net income.
Including Sikorsky, earnings are expected to be $6.55 to $6.85 per share, down from earlier expectations of $6.85 to $7.05.
The decline in the earnings expectation is primarily due to one-time separation costs and lower contributions from Sikorsky due to weakness in the oil and gas markets.
The Procter & Gamble Company ( PG ) has sold three of its beauty businesses to Coty Inc. ( COTY ) for $12 billion, according to reports.
The three P&G businesses auctioned include hair care, fragrances and cosmetics.
The deal is part of its plan to strengthen its portfolio and streamline the business.
However, the deal has not yet been finalized.
Neither company has yet issued an official statement.
Coty is said to have outbid other potential buyers during the auction.
Coty is known for its perfume for fashion brands Calvin Klein and Marc Jacobs.
The company has a market value of $9.39 billion.
Coty, which has been acquiring brands for years, will particularly benefit from this deal.
The company will enjoy the huge customer base that P&G has across the globe.

General Electric Company ( GE ) announced that with the completion of the recent wave of asset offloading, GE Capital Real Estate business has now completed deals aggregating $9.5 billion with several high-profile banks and other buyers for portfolios in Canada, Germany, Japan, U.K. and the U.S.

Blackstone and Wells Fargo will purchase $22.5 billion of GE's real estate debt and equity assets, as announced by the conglomerate on Apr 10.
Further, on May 29, Shinsei Bank acquired a $0.5 billion portfolio of assets in Japan from GE.
Transactions worth an additional $3.5 billion of debt and equity assets are pending, located largely in France, Germany, Italy, Japan Spain, the U.K. and the U.S.
Most of these deals are expected to conclude in the second and third quarter of this year.
Cisco Systems Inc. 's ( CSCO ) Chief Executive John Chambers, and his successor, Chuck Robbins, met Chinese Vice Premier Wang Yang and other government leaders in Beijing.
Cisco announced that over the next several years, it will make investments and partnerships of more than $10 billion in the country.
Cisco did not mention any explicit investment target or time frame.
However, the company signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with China's top economic-planning body, the National Development and Reform Commission.
The company said that it will invest on fund innovation, equity investment, research and development (R&D), and job creation.
